description: The Cloud Fundamentals video series is designed to introduce the viewer to cloud computing, which works from providers that can have thousands of servers and have more than enough hardware and CPU resources to support their systems and they rent out the extra capacity to users so the potential is not wasted. Positions like system administrators, developers and CIOs all benefit from implementing cloud technology. Cloud concepts and theory are discussed and then actual deployment examples of practical applications are demonstrated using Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure.
name: Cloud Fundamentals
subtitle: Introduction to cloud computing

episodes.title: What is the Cloud?
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,606
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,606 --> 00:00:11,451
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,451 --> 00:00:14,930
Greetings, and welcome to another
great episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:14,930 --> 00:00:16,360
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16,360 --> 00:00:18,420
Here with me today is none
other than Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18,420 --> 00:00:19,770
How you doing today Don?

7
00:00:19,770 --> 00:00:20,800
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:20,800 --> 00:00:23,900
And you know I'm excited to
kick off a new series here on

9
00:00:23,900 --> 00:00:27,060
ITProTV our Cloud Fundamentals.

10
00:00:27,060 --> 00:00:30,935
This is going to be a series of episodes
all tailored to introducing you

11
00:00:30,935 --> 00:00:35,088
the viewer, to the cloud which is like
the most nebulous term in the world.

12
00:00:35,088 --> 00:00:37,336
Well, I guess nebula's are clouds I
don't know how that works out, or not.

13
00:00:37,336 --> 00:00:38,885
But it's a buzz word that
gets thrown around a lot.

14
00:00:38,885 --> 00:00:41,715
A lot a lot of people don't really
realize what's going on with it.

15
00:00:41,715 --> 00:00:45,005
So we're gonna decipher the mystery and
kind of thin that out.

16
00:00:45,005 --> 00:00:48,295
We're going to start off with a few
episodes that are just going to detail

17
00:00:48,295 --> 00:00:49,530
cloud concepts.

18
00:00:49,530 --> 00:00:51,990
And then we're going to follow off
with some real world examples.

19
00:00:51,990 --> 00:00:55,170
Show you how to implement cloud
technologies, how to make use of them.

20
00:00:55,170 --> 00:00:59,240
We'll get some chances to see, like,
Amazon EC2, and Microsoft Azure, and

21
00:00:59,240 --> 00:01:00,840
those guys in action.

22
00:01:00,840 --> 00:01:05,020
But before we dive into all that,
let's just start with the basics.

23
00:01:05,020 --> 00:01:06,410
What is the cloud?

24
00:01:07,460 --> 00:01:08,790
Now, if somebody comes to you and
says, hey,

25
00:01:08,790 --> 00:01:12,840
I need to get my stuff in the cloud,
they could mean several different things.

26
00:01:12,840 --> 00:01:17,970
So let's back it all the way back up
to where this technology came from,

27
00:01:17,970 --> 00:01:19,100
back in the 1970s.

28
00:01:19,100 --> 00:01:21,280
That's right, we're gonna go,
we're going old school.

29
00:01:21,280 --> 00:01:23,415
So back 40 years ago.

30
00:01:23,415 --> 00:01:26,635
We started to see virtualize
computing infrastructure.

31
00:01:26,635 --> 00:01:30,065
He's on a mainframe mostly like the old
VAC systems and things like that.

32
00:01:30,065 --> 00:01:31,885
They had virtualization in them.

33
00:01:31,885 --> 00:01:36,535
And then the technology kind of died off
in the late 80s and then in the late 90s,

34
00:01:36,535 --> 00:01:38,835
it started to come back again.

35
00:01:38,835 --> 00:01:42,825
And we started seeing this
virtualization movement kick in, and

36
00:01:42,825 --> 00:01:44,880
it's what really led to the cloud.

37
00:01:44,880 --> 00:01:48,550
So virtualization is really the heart of
this and if you don't know what that is.

38
00:01:48,550 --> 00:01:52,570
Well virtualization is probably one of the
coolest technologies to be implemented on

39
00:01:52,570 --> 00:01:54,040
modern networks.

40
00:01:54,040 --> 00:01:58,910
What it is, the way I always describe it,
is it's kind of like car pooling for

41
00:01:58,910 --> 00:02:00,290
computers, right?

42
00:02:00,290 --> 00:02:01,800
If you think about your car.

43
00:02:01,800 --> 00:02:05,858
I drove to the studio this morning
in a car that has five seats in it,

44
00:02:05,858 --> 00:02:07,750
and I was the only person in it.

45
00:02:07,750 --> 00:02:12,390
So that meant I had four seats in my car
that were empty that I could've used,

46
00:02:12,390 --> 00:02:13,320
but I waste it.

47
00:02:13,320 --> 00:02:15,760
So I really only use 20% of
the potential of my vehicle,

48
00:02:15,760 --> 00:02:17,730
as far as moving people
from one place to another.

49
00:02:17,730 --> 00:02:19,830
Well that's where your computer is.

50
00:02:19,830 --> 00:02:21,780
I've got a laptop sitting
here in front of me.

51
00:02:21,780 --> 00:02:23,760
It's got 16 gigs of RAM in it.

52
00:02:23,760 --> 00:02:26,650
I'm probably using two
gigs of ram right now.

53
00:02:26,650 --> 00:02:29,050
The other memory just wasted.

54
00:02:29,050 --> 00:02:31,600
CPU, I don't really know.

55
00:02:31,600 --> 00:02:34,000
I think I've got a quad-core processor.

56
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:35,120
Show's what I know.

57
00:02:35,120 --> 00:02:39,070
So I'm probably using one CPU, and
barely a percent is that right now.

58
00:02:39,070 --> 00:02:40,980
The rest of it is being wasted.

59
00:02:40,980 --> 00:02:42,170
That's how our computers are.

60
00:02:42,170 --> 00:02:45,570
We waste a lot of resources,
but we want them

61
00:02:45,570 --> 00:02:48,670
because there will come a time when
I need it, where I need that memory.

62
00:02:48,670 --> 00:02:50,910
I need that CPU, and I need it to be here.

63
00:02:50,910 --> 00:02:53,130
So, I have it, and
I just waste what's extra.

64
00:02:54,180 --> 00:02:58,633
With virtualization what we do, is we
take more than one operating system and

65
00:02:58,633 --> 00:03:00,420
we run it on the same computer.

66
00:03:00,420 --> 00:03:02,220
We run it on the same hardware.

67
00:03:02,220 --> 00:03:05,690
And now, you know, I might only
be using two gigs of memory, but

68
00:03:05,690 --> 00:03:08,110
I've got another operating system
that's using two more gigs.

69
00:03:08,110 --> 00:03:10,150
And a third operating system
that's using two more.

70
00:03:10,150 --> 00:03:12,930
And between the three of us
we're all using six gigs of RAM.

71
00:03:12,930 --> 00:03:15,830
Now we're actually starting to use
the hardware that's available to us,

72
00:03:15,830 --> 00:03:17,780
we're starting to get our money's worth.

73
00:03:17,780 --> 00:03:20,900
And that's the principle
behind virtualization.

74
00:03:20,900 --> 00:03:23,500
That's where products like VMWare,
vSphere and

75
00:03:23,500 --> 00:03:28,510
Microsoft HyperV, Citrix Zen Server,
KVM, all those other different software

76
00:03:28,510 --> 00:03:31,850
virtualization products that are out
there, and their hardware counterparts.

77
00:03:31,850 --> 00:03:36,480
All of that works on the simple
principle of carpooling for servers.

78
00:03:37,510 --> 00:03:41,150
Well, once that started to catch on,
and remember,

79
00:03:41,150 --> 00:03:43,120
this really came about in the 1970s.

80
00:03:43,120 --> 00:03:47,870
But it wasn't until the late 90s that
VMWare really pushed into businesses.

81
00:03:47,870 --> 00:03:52,430
And we're to a point now in the year 2015,
where If you're a business and

82
00:03:52,430 --> 00:03:55,480
you don't have virtualization of one form
or another, you're behind the curve.

83
00:03:55,480 --> 00:03:59,340
Everybody's pretty much implement
this in one form or another.

84
00:03:59,340 --> 00:04:03,300
Well, providers like Amazon, Microsoft.

85
00:04:03,300 --> 00:04:07,060
These companies that are huge, that tens
of thousands of servers around the world.

86
00:04:07,060 --> 00:04:12,800
Google, Rackspace these guys have tons
of hardware to support their systems.

87
00:04:12,800 --> 00:04:14,570
And it's more than they need.

88
00:04:14,570 --> 00:04:18,100
And so what do they do with
the extra stuff goes to waste?

89
00:04:18,100 --> 00:04:19,570
Well used to,

90
00:04:19,570 --> 00:04:25,030
now thanks to virtualization they can
rent out their extra space to customers.

91
00:04:25,030 --> 00:04:30,190
If you need a server with a certain amount
of memory, instead of building yourself

92
00:04:30,190 --> 00:04:33,825
you can just go rent it from Microsoft's
leftovers, or Amazon's leftovers.

93
00:04:33,825 --> 00:04:35,220
Because they got a ton, right?

94
00:04:35,220 --> 00:04:36,990
Tens of thousands of us around the globe.

95
00:04:36,990 --> 00:04:39,290
Google, they probably
have the most of anybody.

96
00:04:39,290 --> 00:04:43,300
They've got reserves, they've got extra
CPU, extra memory laying around, and

97
00:04:43,300 --> 00:04:45,000
I don't mean like chips laying on a shelf.

98
00:04:45,000 --> 00:04:47,025
Although they they do that too.

99
00:04:47,025 --> 00:04:48,632
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I mean,

100
00:04:48,632 --> 00:04:50,660
active servers that are running,
connected to the Internet.

101
00:04:50,660 --> 00:04:53,470
That just aren't being used to
they're fullest utilization.

102
00:04:53,470 --> 00:04:55,640
And we can take advantage of that.

103
00:04:55,640 --> 00:04:57,820
And that is the cloud.

104
00:04:57,820 --> 00:04:59,470
It's using these servers.

105
00:04:59,470 --> 00:05:01,530
These things that
are connected to the internet.

106
00:05:01,530 --> 00:05:02,600
They just aren't being used right now.

107
00:05:02,600 --> 00:05:05,130
It's just kind of available and
being wasted.

108
00:05:05,130 --> 00:05:09,210
So you can thank technologies
like VMware ESX server.

109
00:05:09,210 --> 00:05:10,500
Or Microsoft's Hyper V.

110
00:05:10,500 --> 00:05:13,510
Or Virtual Box, or any of
the virtualization products out there.

111
00:05:13,510 --> 00:05:16,700
For leading to what we all
think of today as a cloud.

112
00:05:16,700 --> 00:05:18,200
>> And it's very convenient too.

113
00:05:18,200 --> 00:05:22,710
I love virtualization, to be able to run
mobile operating systems on my laptop,

114
00:05:22,710 --> 00:05:24,340
kind of like Don was talking about.

115
00:05:24,340 --> 00:05:29,000
But the cost of it is so
much more economical than me going, well,

116
00:05:29,000 --> 00:05:33,030
I need another server, or
I need another, even a desktop system.

117
00:05:33,030 --> 00:05:35,910
I don't have to actually buy that system.

118
00:05:35,910 --> 00:05:38,730
I can say hey I can use one
of these cloud technologies.

119
00:05:38,730 --> 00:05:39,820
I can go to Amazon.

120
00:05:39,820 --> 00:05:42,350
I can go to Microsoft Azure and
use some of that.

121
00:05:42,350 --> 00:05:45,450
And let them foot the bill, and
take care of all that stuff.

122
00:05:45,450 --> 00:05:47,220
I just need the server to run.

123
00:05:47,220 --> 00:05:49,140
Makes it really simple for me.

124
00:05:49,140 --> 00:05:51,890
>> Now where it gets confusing is,

125
00:05:51,890 --> 00:05:55,170
when you decide to implement
a technology in the cloud.

126
00:05:55,170 --> 00:05:59,050
You have different layers, different
levels that you can kind of buy in.

127
00:05:59,050 --> 00:06:00,440
It's like a poker game.

128
00:06:00,440 --> 00:06:01,780
You can you can bet a little bit, or

129
00:06:01,780 --> 00:06:04,280
you can go all in and
put all your chips into that bet.

130
00:06:04,280 --> 00:06:06,450
Well that's how the cloud is.

131
00:06:06,450 --> 00:06:10,130
So when you reach out and you start
to reserve these cloud resources.

132
00:06:10,130 --> 00:06:12,800
It's up to you how far in you want to go,
all right?

133
00:06:12,800 --> 00:06:15,560
Some people just tab their
toe in a little bit.

134
00:06:15,560 --> 00:06:17,010
They rent that server hardware.

135
00:06:17,010 --> 00:06:20,560
They go to Amazon EC2 or
they go to Microsoft Azure, and

136
00:06:20,560 --> 00:06:22,700
they rent CPU and memory.

137
00:06:22,700 --> 00:06:24,500
And they put their
operating system on there.

138
00:06:24,500 --> 00:06:25,910
They put their software on there.

139
00:06:25,910 --> 00:06:28,660
They manage it just like they would
a server in their own environment.

140
00:06:28,660 --> 00:06:32,140
But the hardware is what's
out there in the cloud.

141
00:06:32,140 --> 00:06:35,360
And they're renting that from that
provider whoever that happens to be,

142
00:06:35,360 --> 00:06:37,120
to get the access to that system.

143
00:06:37,120 --> 00:06:39,670
Now that's one way to go about it.

144
00:06:39,670 --> 00:06:44,260
And the nice part there is the hardware
is completely handled by that vendor.

145
00:06:44,260 --> 00:06:45,630
You don't have to worry about it.

146
00:06:45,630 --> 00:06:47,980
You manage everything
else as far as the OS.

147
00:06:47,980 --> 00:06:49,800
Just like you would a server
sitting right next to you.

148
00:06:49,800 --> 00:06:51,940
So it's easy to implement that way, and

149
00:06:51,940 --> 00:06:55,330
you start to take advantage of some
of what the cloud has to offer.

150
00:06:56,640 --> 00:06:58,280
Then we can go a step further.

151
00:06:58,280 --> 00:07:01,760
And we can say, well you know what,
they're managing our hardware.

152
00:07:01,760 --> 00:07:04,710
Wouldn't it be nice if they
managed the operating system too?

153
00:07:04,710 --> 00:07:07,090
And now they can manage the hardware and
the operating system, and

154
00:07:07,090 --> 00:07:08,810
we just throw our software on top.

155
00:07:08,810 --> 00:07:10,840
And now we just have to
keep track of our software.

156
00:07:10,840 --> 00:07:13,290
That's a little bit further
into the cloud, right?

157
00:07:13,290 --> 00:07:16,810
Now you're starting to kind of eliminate

158
00:07:16,810 --> 00:07:20,360
your ability to control certain
areas as far as hardware and the OS.

159
00:07:20,360 --> 00:07:22,940
And then there's going all in.

160
00:07:22,940 --> 00:07:25,480
And going all in,
that's where you say, you know what?

161
00:07:25,480 --> 00:07:28,010
I want this provider out there on
the cloud to take care of the hardware,

162
00:07:28,010 --> 00:07:30,300
the operating system, the software,
the whole nine yards.

163
00:07:30,300 --> 00:07:32,480
I just wanna use my programs.

164
00:07:32,480 --> 00:07:36,130
And that's really where
most of our consumers are.

165
00:07:36,130 --> 00:07:39,130
And most of you guys who are watching
the show are probably doing this.

166
00:07:39,130 --> 00:07:44,170
If you if you use web based email, like I
use Gmail for some of my personal email.

167
00:07:44,170 --> 00:07:47,586
And with Google, they provide the servers,
they provide the OS,

168
00:07:47,586 --> 00:07:49,052
they provide the software.

169
00:07:49,052 --> 00:07:51,420
I just log into a web page and
there's my email.

170
00:07:51,420 --> 00:07:53,541
I didn't configure anything.

171
00:07:53,541 --> 00:07:58,766
On one hand, I get super easy to use
email that is on world class servers and

172
00:07:58,766 --> 00:08:04,610
world class data centers,
it's really more than I could do myself.

173
00:08:04,610 --> 00:08:07,300
On the other hand,
I have zero control of that server.

174
00:08:07,300 --> 00:08:11,750
If I say, boy,
I really wish they offered S/MIME support.

175
00:08:12,790 --> 00:08:15,868
Well, they don't, and
there's nothing I can do about that.

176
00:08:15,868 --> 00:08:20,110
In fact, there's no real way to contact
Google to even ask them, right.

177
00:08:20,110 --> 00:08:25,140
So you're really leaving it up to
them to control those features and

178
00:08:25,140 --> 00:08:27,980
so on,
we're just not able to deal with that.

179
00:08:27,980 --> 00:08:30,290
So that's one of the challenges
that you bump into.

180
00:08:30,290 --> 00:08:34,640
If you need a lot of control, going
full cloud is not necessarily an option.

181
00:08:34,640 --> 00:08:36,220
You might have to go with
one of the smaller options.

182
00:08:36,220 --> 00:08:37,810
So that's something we
need to be aware of,

183
00:08:37,810 --> 00:08:41,380
is that there are different levels of
buy in when it comes to using the cloud.

184
00:08:41,380 --> 00:08:45,760
>> Now Don, is there necessarily a right
or wrong implementation of the cloud, or

185
00:08:45,760 --> 00:08:50,410
it's just whatever's curtailed to your-
>> According to the trade magazines,

186
00:08:50,410 --> 00:08:51,114
they're all right.

187
00:08:51,114 --> 00:08:54,473
>> [LAUGH]
>> You should be using the cloud!

188
00:08:54,473 --> 00:08:58,880
I think that it's not so much about being
wrong as it is being sub-optimal, right.

189
00:08:58,880 --> 00:09:03,280
That there's some people that have certain
needs, and when you go into the cloud,

190
00:09:03,280 --> 00:09:07,210
you might not be taking advantage
of all that the cloud has to offer.

191
00:09:07,210 --> 00:09:11,350
Or maybe you're taking into too much,
and now you've put yourself at risk.

192
00:09:11,350 --> 00:09:14,420
Like if your company handles
financial records or medical records,

193
00:09:14,420 --> 00:09:18,950
you might put too much data into the cloud
and then the cloud gets compromised.

194
00:09:18,950 --> 00:09:21,190
And now those records are out and
you have a debacle.

195
00:09:21,190 --> 00:09:24,090
You should have maintained more control so
you can encrypt your data and

196
00:09:24,090 --> 00:09:25,180
guarantee security.

197
00:09:25,180 --> 00:09:27,370
So you do have to be careful
about things like that.

198
00:09:27,370 --> 00:09:29,030
But it's not so much about right or

199
00:09:29,030 --> 00:09:33,540
wrong as it is just making sure
that you take proper precautions.

200
00:09:33,540 --> 00:09:38,430
So, all right, now when we go into
the cloud what most people think of

201
00:09:38,430 --> 00:09:42,420
as the cloud is is what's actually
called the public cloud, all right.

202
00:09:42,420 --> 00:09:46,000
Amazon's Web services,
Microsoft Azure, Rackspace,

203
00:09:46,000 --> 00:09:50,540
OpenStack, those guys they're
providing public clouds.

204
00:09:50,540 --> 00:09:53,760
A server infrastructure with
tens of thousands of servers

205
00:09:53,760 --> 00:09:55,520
that are exposed to the Internet.

206
00:09:55,520 --> 00:10:00,150
So if I bring a web server up
in Amazon EC2, well by default

207
00:10:00,150 --> 00:10:03,805
it's got a public IP on the Internet, and
if I open up port 80 on its firewall,

208
00:10:03,805 --> 00:10:07,705
the whole Internet can see that server and
browse and get access to it, all right.

209
00:10:07,705 --> 00:10:11,635
That's a public cloud, and
if you're gonna be running a website,

210
00:10:11,635 --> 00:10:15,195
an email server, or something of that
nature, you want it to be public.

211
00:10:16,465 --> 00:10:19,435
But there's also private clouds.

212
00:10:19,435 --> 00:10:24,630
Private clouds are ones where you set up
the cloud in your own infrastructure.

213
00:10:24,630 --> 00:10:27,420
So for example,
let's say that I needed a cloud.

214
00:10:27,420 --> 00:10:29,370
I want to be able to rapidly
provision servers and

215
00:10:29,370 --> 00:10:31,900
all that good stuff that we
hear about with these clouds.

216
00:10:31,900 --> 00:10:34,650
I could go ahead and go and
buy 100 servers, and

217
00:10:34,650 --> 00:10:36,110
I could set them up right
here behind the set.

218
00:10:36,110 --> 00:10:37,170
I'll stick them behind this wall, right.

219
00:10:37,170 --> 00:10:39,519
I'll just stack 100 servers and
it'll get hot as heck in here.

220
00:10:39,519 --> 00:10:41,960
[LAUGH] So we'll set up those 100 servers.

221
00:10:41,960 --> 00:10:44,550
And now I can set it up with
cloud software to be able to

222
00:10:44,550 --> 00:10:46,930
rapidly provision machines,
get that up and running.

223
00:10:46,930 --> 00:10:47,950
I can do it.

224
00:10:47,950 --> 00:10:50,880
It's private because I control everything.

225
00:10:50,880 --> 00:10:53,400
It's my hardware, it's my operating
system, it's my software,

226
00:10:53,400 --> 00:10:57,630
I'm not really outsourcing anything,
it's a private cloud completely here, but

227
00:10:57,630 --> 00:10:59,830
the negative is I've got to manage it.

228
00:10:59,830 --> 00:11:03,760
I'm not getting all the advantages of
using some external cloud provider when

229
00:11:03,760 --> 00:11:10,280
you use, let's just use,
we used Amazon EC2 as an example.

230
00:11:10,280 --> 00:11:11,970
They're taking care of the hardware.

231
00:11:11,970 --> 00:11:15,810
I manage the OS, I manage the software,
but they're taking care of the hardware.

00:11:15,810 --> 00:11:17,120
When I say they're taking

233
00:11:17,120 --> 00:11:21,390
that means they buy the physical server,
they keep it under warranty.

234
00:11:21,390 --> 00:11:24,120
If a hard drive fails, they replace it.

235
00:11:24,120 --> 00:11:27,910
If power goes out,
they've got UPSes, generators,

00:11:27,910 --> 00:11:30,110

The server is in a physical rack that

00:11:35,630 --> 00:11:39,310

00:11:39,310 --> 00:11:44,100
That's all stuff that Amazon does, and

And in exchange I just paid a simple

00:11:48,220 --> 00:11:51,550

00:11:51,550 --> 00:11:53,540
I'm only doing it 100 times, right.

00:11:53,540 --> 00:11:55,620
So economies of scale, right.

00:11:55,620 --> 00:11:57,230
That's what happens with

00:11:57,230 --> 00:12:00,220
With the private ones,
you pay the power bill,

00:12:00,220 --> 00:12:03,860

if a hard drive fails you replace it.

00:12:03,860 --> 00:12:05,120
You do all that maintenance.

248
00:12:05,120 --> 00:12:07,660
So, why would we do that?

00:12:07,660 --> 00:12:10,350
Control, if I need
control of those servers,

00:12:10,350 --> 00:12:14,290
if I need to guarantee a level of

251
00:12:14,290 --> 00:12:17,090
If we need that level of control,
but most people don't, and

252
00:12:17,090 --> 00:12:20,260
that's where you can really
take advantage of the cloud.

253
00:12:20,260 --> 00:12:25,030
Now the best implementation in my opinion,
is what's called a hybrid cloud, and

00:12:25,030 --> 00:12:27,140

00:12:27,140 --> 00:12:30,480
You have public resources

256
00:12:30,480 --> 00:12:33,720

and you can link the two together.

257
00:12:33,720 --> 00:12:37,030
And there's a lot of neat products
out there that let you do this.

258
00:12:37,030 --> 00:12:40,180
I mentioned Rackspace's OpenStack,
that's one.

00:12:40,180 --> 00:12:43,590
Microsoft System Center Virtual
Machine Manager, that's another.

00:12:43,590 --> 00:12:46,080

00:12:46,080 --> 00:12:47,634
VMware, their, shoot what's their?

00:12:48,303 --> 00:12:49,231
No.

00:12:49,231 --> 00:12:51,129

vCenter Orchestrator, which actually, I

00:12:54,658 --> 00:12:58,200

00:12:58,200 --> 00:13:04,830
These products let you create a private

00:13:04,830 --> 00:13:09,950

Maybe I've got a web server,

00:13:13,210 --> 00:13:14,750

It's in the public cloud.

And, if I'm having some problems with

00:13:53,170 --> 00:13:56,750
It allows us to create a hybrid

most people use that for

I'm moving my company to the cloud,

00:14:07,730 --> 00:14:11,220
I've got some data, this is private, it's

00:14:13,750 --> 00:14:16,779
Now, we get the best of both worlds.

00:14:16,779 --> 00:14:20,168
All right, so that's definitely something

00:14:20,168 --> 00:14:23,630

it's gonna be your baby.

If I'm a developer I can really take
